DataElement.preferredName: Person Current Drug Abuse Agent Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text names of substance(s) used by a person for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed. [Manually-curated]

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the personal medical history (the reporting of medical events) of intravenous (within a blood vessel) drug abuse (the use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed) in a person._Occurring in or belonging to the present time._The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed.

Property.preferredDefinition: Occurring in or belonging to the present time.:The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed.

Concepts.definition: Occurring in or belonging to the present time.
The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Observations and activities relating to behavior, such as smoking and ETOH use.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed._An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect. (NCI)_The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (in-tra-VEE-nus) IV. Within a blood vessel.: The abuse potential category to which an active ingredient, or combination of active ingredients, is assigned, as regulated by both the United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the United States Food and Drug Administration.

Concepts.definition: Into or within a vein. Intravenous usually refers to a way of giving a drug or other substance through a needle or tube inserted into a vein.

The abuse potential category to which an active ingredient, or combination of active ingredients, is assigned, as regulated by both the United States Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the United States Food and Drug Administration.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A narcotic analgesic that may be habit-forming. It is a controlled substance (opium derivative) listed in the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, Title 21 Parts 329.1, 1308.11 (1987). Sale is forbidden in the United States by Federal statute. (Merck Index, 11th ed)

Concepts.definition: A narcotic analgesic that may be habit-forming. It is a controlled substance (opium derivative) listed in the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations, Title 21 Parts 329.1, 1308.11 (1987). Sale is forbidden in the United States by Federal statute. (Merck Index, 11th ed)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A psychologically and socially impaired state, with or without physiological changes, that develops as a result of using cocaine and which leads to compulsive behaviors to acquire the substance.

Concepts.definition: A psychologically and socially impaired state, with or without physiological changes, that develops as a result of using cocaine and which leads to compulsive behaviors to acquire the substance.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any part of, or extract from, the female hemp plant Cannabis sativa.  Marijuana contains cannabinoids, substances with hallucinogenic, psychoactive, and addictive properties.  This agent has potential use for treating cancer pain and cachexia. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: Any part of, or extract from, the female hemp plant Cannabis sativa.  Marijuana contains cannabinoids, substances with hallucinogenic, psychoactive, and addictive properties.  This agent has potential use for treating cancer pain and cachexia. (NCI04)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Observations and activities relating to behavior, such as smoking and ETOH use.

(NCI):The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: The use of a drug for a reason other than which it was intended or in a manner or in quantities other than directed.
An active power or cause (as principle, substance, physical or biological factor, etc.) that produces a specific effect.
The words or language units by which a thing is known.
